revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-09 11:03:40.000000000', 'message': 'Fix issues obtaining Keystone token with Monasca Grafana

When using the the default domain name there are issues authenticating
with Keystone. For example, you can only log in on the second attempt
and the Monasca datasource fails to authenticate. Switching to the
default domain id resolves these issues.

Change-Id: I2cb4b2608c74dd853c97e4fc27078930bc72fdf8
'}]
commit_message:
Fix issues obtaining Keystone token with Monasca Grafana

When using the the default domain name there are issues authenticating
with Keystone. For example, you can only log in on the second attempt
and the Monasca datasource fails to authenticate. Switching to the
default domain id resolves these issues.

Change-Id: I2cb4b2608c74dd853c97e4fc27078930bc72fdf8

commit_message:
Supporting monitoring time synchronisation with Monasca

This plugin is useful for monitoring host clock synchronisation with
an NTP reference. If the delta becomes too large, the metrics from
this plugin can be used to trigger an alarm.

Change-Id: Id1fe6d7c823f8404c19c81ccdeb8b311bcb46e47

[{'created': '2019-06-05 18:36:37.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid duplicating Nova cells

Check if a base Nova cell (named cell1 by default) already exists before
calling `nova-manage cell_v2 create_cell`, which would otherwise create
a duplicated cell when the transport URL or database connection change.

If a base cell already exists but the connection values have changed, we
now call `nova-manage cell_v2 update_cell` instead.

Change-Id: I7841ce0cff08e315fd7761d84e1e681b1a00d43e

If a base cell already exists but the connection values have changed, we
now call `nova-manage cell_v2 update_cell` instead. This is only
possible if a duplicate cell has not yet been created. If one already
exists, we print a warning inviting the operator to perform a manual
cleanup. We don't use a hard fail to avoid an abrupt change of behavior

Change-Id: I7841ce0cff08e315fd7761d84e1e681b1a00d43e
Closes-Bug: #1734872

commit_message:
Stop duplicating Nova cells

Check if a base Nova cell already exists before calling `nova-manage
cell_v2 create_cell`, which would otherwise create a duplicate cell when
the transport URL or database connection change.

If a base cell already exists but the connection values have changed, we
now call `nova-manage cell_v2 update_cell` instead. This is only
possible if a duplicate cell has not yet been created. If one already
exists, we print a warning inviting the operator to perform a manual
cleanup. We don't use a hard fail to avoid an abrupt change of behavior
if this is backported to stable branches.

Change-Id: I7841ce0cff08e315fd7761d84e1e681b1a00d43e
Closes-Bug: #1734872

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-07 14:25:02.000000000', 'message': 'Replace hardcoded gather_facts:no with variable

Use a gather_facts variable to control fact gathering at the play level
instead of just the hardcoded gather_facts:no.

This allows for forcing facts to be gathered during a play if the
earlier fact gathering tasks had been skipped (such as when using
--start-at-task).

commit_message:
Replace hardcoded gather_facts:no with variable

Use a gather_facts variable to control fact gathering at the play level
instead of just the hardcoded gather_facts:no.

This allows for forcing facts to be gathered during a play if the
earlier fact gathering tasks had been skipped (such as when using
--start-at-task).

Change-Id: I2b7625baac4a09413cc50b84d2df1c00ec14b00a

'}]
commit_message:
Fix issues with Percona in Zuul and clean up a little bit

Percona site has connectivity issues from OVH hosts (of Zuul).
This patch makes it so that:
  - the internal repo is actually used
  - RPM GPG keys are downloaded from the actually used repo
  - Ubuntu mimics the RHEL behavior (i.e. the Percona repo is
    enabled only in the xtrabackup image)
    extra benefit: no need for APT preferences for Percona repo
    to spare MariaDB deps

Change-Id: Id27831f6b404762f9e44fd6bd1c4702bf06b05f8
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Debian/Ubuntu: allow to use unsigned repositories

When we run Debian 'buster' or Ubuntu 18.04 in CI job they refuse to
work as infra mirror is not signed.

This patch instructs APT to use unsigned repos anyway.

Change-Id: I530fde5b57894afda2de98d7c217e735497e3feb

commit_message:
set ignore_basepython_conflict = True in tox.ini

os-vif sets the base python version globally in the
base testenv and relies on tox to pick up the
correct python version form the env name for standard
envs like py27.

This behavior only work reliably if
ignore_basepython_conflict = True is set.

Change-Id: I458cf6cf88d9ee672d6cce59e1d86ed888957042
Closes-Bug: #1832652

commit_message:
Add helper playbook to create new roles

A playbook has been added to the root of the project which will assist
developers in adding new roles to the project. The playbook will generate
a new role, create a tox entry, and setup zuul for independent CI.

This new playbook capability has been added to the contributing docs.

Change-Id: I726740e1c95b2f38fe7bae2e9a8f1e35feb5a7bf
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add test_deps role and basic molecule job

This change creates a role named test_dep which will be used by all
roles tested with molecule. This role is iteself is also tested with
molecule. To ensure the CI is able to run these jobs as independent
tox environments a zuul job was setup which will execute setup the
ci node and execute the tox environment.

Depends-On: Ib1749721b32b21ba1ab661a64097d79037e416f3
Change-Id: Idc784fa03c15c56d0f516f4db2e9cb5eee463fae
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

[{'account_id': 29100, 'date': '2019-06-05 13:16:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-06-05 13:19:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2019-06-05 15:08:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28614, 'date': '2019-06-06 11:17:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-06-06 14:30:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

As I think you highlighted in IRC, we need a change in kolla since the domain is created there.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-06-06 14:30:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2019-06-06 14:46:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2019-06-13 17:48:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> As I think you highlighted in IRC, we need a change in kolla since

As I bumped into this today, I thought I would share the link to the code being discussed: https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/src/branch/master/docker/heat/heat-api/extend_start.sh'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-05 13:16:24.000000000', 'message': 'Allow overriding heat domain/user names

Most of the other Heat users and accounts are overridable by the
consumer. This makes that also true of the stack domain admin and also
the domain name. Default values are preserved.

Change-Id: Ie2e26dd09d5a8ec88de4760a9a92ed06c00cbb76
'}]
commit_message:
Allow overriding heat domain/user names

Most of the other Heat users and accounts are overridable by the
consumer. This makes that also true of the stack domain admin and also
the domain name. Default values are preserved.

Change-Id: Ie2e26dd09d5a8ec88de4760a9a92ed06c00cbb76

[{'created': '2019-06-12 23:00:32.000000000', 'message': 'Disable the kdump service in the amphora

We have also seen instances where kdump is causing the boot to fail
because the amphora image requires so little RAM the auto memory
allocation for kdump reserves zero RAM.

This element disables the kdump service in the amphora as it requires
RAM and since we actively manage the amphora it is unlikely the crash file
will be around long enough to be analyzed.

Change-Id: I3eebcf374ca6350a530ce44a3ecccac926773186

[{'created': '2019-06-11 19:14:31.000000000', 'message': 'Fix lower-constraints test fail due to failing dep build

Ubuntu Bionic updated OpenSSL package to new release:
from 1.1.0 to 1.1.1
It caused cryptography in version from lower-constraints
to fail to build.
Additionally, constrained cryptography version did not
match the requirement for constrained PyOpenSSL.
This commit bumps the version to the minimum required
by constrained PyOpenSSL.
This version agrees also with upper-constraints for Queens.

Change-Id: I8ae19f212049cae5dfb4e8dd6ec6cd14a8c46e0e
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-06-11 19:52:40.000000000', 'message': "Fix lower-constraints test fail due to failing dep build

Ubuntu Bionic updated OpenSSL package to new release:
from 1.1.0 to 1.1.1
It caused cryptography in version from lower-constraints
to fail to build in Zuul.
Additionally, constrained cryptography version did not
match the requirement for constrained PyOpenSSL.
This commit bumps the version to the minimum required
by constrained PyOpenSSL.
It works because manylinux1 (binary) wheel exists.
This version agrees also with upper-constraints for Queens.

Dependency on cryptography is removed as it is not used directly
by kolla (and requirements checker requires lower-constraints
matching version - let's not create an illusion of usage).

Change-Id: I8ae19f212049cae5dfb4e8dd6ec6cd14a8c46e0e
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Fix lower-constraints test fail due to failing dep build

Ubuntu Bionic updated OpenSSL package to new release:
from 1.1.0 to 1.1.1
It caused cryptography in version from lower-constraints
to fail to build in Zuul.
Additionally, constrained cryptography version did not
match the requirement for constrained PyOpenSSL.
This commit bumps the version to the minimum required
by constrained PyOpenSSL.
It works because manylinux1 (binary) wheel exists.
This version agrees also with upper-constraints for Queens.

Dependency on cryptography is removed as it is not used directly
by kolla (and requirements checker requires lower-constraints
matching version - let's not create an illusion of usage).

Change-Id: I8ae19f212049cae5dfb4e8dd6ec6cd14a8c46e0e
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Fix missing "is_sort_key" for basic vpnaas attributes

Patch [1] introduced need to explicity set with "is_sort_key"
flag to attributes which attribute can be used as sort key.
This patch adds it to base attributes in vpnaas resources, like:
* id,
* tenant_id,
* name,
* subnet_id,
* router_id

This commit also updates sphinx requirements to make requirements
jobs passing.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/653903/

Change-Id: Ibe1aee0346e3fc21215d1b3be8752224aa2c162d
Closes-Bug: #1832225

commit_message:
Add Vault Secret Store Plugin

Barbican can utilize Hashicorp Vault software
as a secret store backend. Added a new plugin
manifest to configure the vault_plugin section.

Change-Id: Idef1bdfd20b4820963e084657b46e07660be248c
(cherry picked from commit 7ab351d8d5cbc4c83bfd2ac2c93b960ce5f2e2c4)

commit_message:
Don't persist retry information into database

When migrating an instance, the retried hosts will no longer be
saved in database.

Change-Id: I6c1de66d718af6f3f4d144e5b6c2261522762e2d
Closes-Bug: #1794252

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-14 10:02:26.000000000', 'message': "Use real block_device_info data in test_blockinfo

A number of tests were passing block_device_info consisting of a
skeleton of manually-created nested dicts. However, block_device_info
actually contains a well-defined set of keys whose values are
DriverBlockDevice objects.

Making this change also highlighted a few inaccuracies in existing
tests which were asserting data which is not produced by
get_disk_mapping when passed real data.

The driver for this change is a subsequent change which adds a field
to block_device_info. The subsequent change causes failures in all of
the modified tests because their hard-coded block_device_info doesn't
contain the new field. This is unnecessarily fragile.

This change is not intended to fix all problems in this module. It is
intended to be a minimal change sufficient not to cause breakage when
we subsequently add local_root to block_device_info.

Change-Id: I83d5f26a1ad578bb5c2c1d7e06cfab2efd4699cb

commit_message:
Use real block_device_info data in libvirt tests

A number of tests were passing block_device_info consisting of a
skeleton of manually-created nested dicts. However, block_device_info
actually contains a well-defined set of keys whose values are
DriverBlockDevice objects.

Making this change also highlighted a few inaccuracies in existing
tests which were asserting data which is not produced by
get_disk_mapping when passed real data.

The driver for this change is a subsequent change which adds a field
to block_device_info. The subsequent change causes failures in all of
the modified tests because their hard-coded block_device_info doesn't
contain the new field. This is unnecessarily fragile, and also very
noisy in the subsequent change.

This change is not intended to fix all problems. It is intended to be
a minimal change sufficient not to cause breakage when we subsequently
add local_root to block_device_info.

Part of bp local-disk-serial-numbers

Change-Id: I83d5f26a1ad578bb5c2c1d7e06cfab2efd4699cb

Change I2a2dbcaf will introduce block_device_info_get_root, which

commit_message:
Rename block_device_info_get_root_device

Change I2a2dbcaf will introduce block_device_info_get_root, which
returns the DriverBlockDevice objects for the root disk.. In that
context block_device_info_get_root_device is very confusingly named.
We rename it to block_device_info_get_root_device_name, which also
better reflects its function.

Part of bp local-disk-serial-numbers

Change-Id: Ieae385ba42d5091a33d80a447be766381c7a6989

subject: Local disk serial numbers for the libvirt driver

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-20 17:29:55.000000000', 'message': "Local disk serial numbers for the libvirt driver

This change implements local disk serial numbers for the libvirt
driver.

The structure passed into drivers containing block device mappings is
block_device_info. This is a dict containing DriverBlockDevice objects
split out into local_root, swap, ephemerals, and block_device_mapping
(volumes). The libvirt driver further processes this structure into
its own mapping of disks to 'disk_info': a dict containing
disk-specific metadata relevant to the hypervisor.

This change adds a serial number to disk_info, which is generated in
the libvirt driver in get_disk_mapping and the disk_info-generating
functions it calls. It then adds this serial number to generated
libvirt config.

The serial number is the volume id of a volume, or the BDM uuid of a
local disk. Previously only volumes had serial numbers, which was
read from connection_info. connection_info is a foreign, supposedly
opaque dict, entirely generated by each individual cinder driver.
Relying on this required every individual cinder driver to add serial
number to connection_info. In practise they do this, and they all set
it to volume id, but by not relying on this we also make the
Nova/Cinder interface slightly cleaner, towards an eventual goal of
connection_info being truly opaque again.

Implements: bp local-disk-serial-numbers

Change-Id: I1d3c192aea0143190a92ecbec06727ac4310e22f

"}, {'created': '2018-01-19 18:00:56.000000000', 'message': "Local disk serial numbers for the libvirt driver

This change implements local disk serial numbers for the libvirt
driver.

The structure passed into drivers containing block device mappings is
block_device_info. This is a dict containing DriverBlockDevice objects
split out into local_root, swap, ephemerals, and block_device_mapping
(volumes). The libvirt driver further processes this structure into
its own mapping of disks to 'disk_info': a dict containing
disk-specific metadata relevant to the hypervisor.

This change adds a serial number to disk_info, which is generated in
the libvirt driver in get_disk_mapping and the disk_info-generating
functions it calls. It then adds this serial number to generated
libvirt config.

The serial number is the volume id of a volume, or the BDM uuid of a
local disk. Previously only volumes had serial numbers, which was
read from connection_info. connection_info is a foreign, supposedly
opaque dict, entirely generated by each individual cinder driver.
Relying on this required every individual cinder driver to add serial
number to connection_info. In practise they do this, and they all set
it to volume id, but by not relying on this we also make the
Nova/Cinder interface slightly cleaner, towards an eventual goal of
connection_info being truly opaque again.

Implements: bp local-disk-serial-numbers

Change-Id: I1d3c192aea0143190a92ecbec06727ac4310e22f

commit_message:
Local disk serial numbers for the libvirt driver

This change implements local disk serial numbers for the libvirt
driver.

The structure passed into drivers containing block device mappings is
block_device_info. This is a dict containing DriverBlockDevice objects
split out into local_root, swap, ephemerals, and block_device_mapping
(volumes). The libvirt driver further processes this structure into
its own mapping of disks to 'disk_info': a dict containing
disk-specific metadata relevant to the hypervisor.

This change adds a serial number to disk_info, which is generated in
the libvirt driver in get_disk_mapping and the disk_info-generating
functions it calls. It then adds this serial number to generated
libvirt config.

The serial number is the volume id of a volume, or the BDM uuid of a
local disk. Previously only volumes had serial numbers, which was
read from connection_info. connection_info is a foreign, supposedly
opaque dict, entirely generated by each individual cinder driver.
Relying on this required every individual cinder driver to add serial
number to connection_info. In practise they do this, and they all set
it to volume id, but by not relying on this we also make the
Nova/Cinder interface slightly cleaner, towards an eventual goal of
connection_info being truly opaque again.

Implements: bp local-disk-serial-numbers

Change-Id: I1d3c192aea0143190a92ecbec06727ac4310e22f

commit_message:
Pass DriverBlockDevice to driver.attach_volume

We previously pulled certain data from DriverBlockDevice to be passed
to attach_volume. Given that DriverBlockDevice is explicitly intended
to be consumed by drivers, we pass the object itself. This will enable
the libvirt driver to use additional BDM data available in
DriverBlockDevice without having to further expand the argument list.

Part of bp local-disk-serial-numbers

Change-Id: Id2bab47aa83d6a7c94fecf2364304000e4f29ecf

commit_message:
Add local_root to block_device_info

block_device_info currently doesn't contain a driver BDM for a local
root disk, meaning it isn't available to drivers. We need this in
order to later expose uuid to drivers.

Part of bp local-disk-serial-numbers

Change-Id: I2a2dbcafe88525ec9f82f172a3bbb19fc9d0c1c7

commit_message:
Add DriverLocalImageBlockDevice

This change adds the DriverBlockDevice class which will be used to
expose local root disk BDMs to drivers. A subsequent change will add
it to the block_device_info struct to actually make it available.

Part of bp local-disk-serial-numbers

Change-Id: I7ba1568875c6cff5c13cec570fb1e424028bbb21

This feels like a good start - follow the LTS version supported upstream. We'll want to move to v12 next year: https://nodejs.org/en/about/releases/

Does all of our current javascript code run on v10? Or is this the target we're moving to? I see some recent work on v10 templates in horizon's zuul config."}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-20 12:16:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Thanks, Graham. I don't know if we have any javascript that isn't
 > appropriate to test on node (browser stuff?) so I'm not sure about
 > saying "all" but I'll leave that wording up to more knowledgeable
 > folks to clarify if it needs it.

In general, testing for browser code runs under node as well. For example, these lines in horizon: https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/f15a8071bb427a39b7bc0809965b22a502c7d9ea/package.json#L23-L25

That's not to say we don't have some really strange code out there where using node doesn't make sense, but we should be striving for "all" :)'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-03-20 14:05:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-03-20 17:04:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Update nodeJS PTI version for Train

Update the nodeJS version that we should use for javascript based testing
in openstack.

Change-Id: I1a594acc8f430c95d3a32f767e5508d0fcc65ac9
Signed-off-by: Graham Hayes <gr@ham.ie>

commit_message:
Don't generate fake disk_info in swap_volume

By using the new get_host_type() and get_host_path() methods of
libvirt volume drivers, we no longer have to generate fake disk_info
in swap_volume().

In changing this, we also change the disk_path argument to disk_dev.
This was clearly a source of confusion: the argument is the name of a
guest device, not a host path. We also fix invalid data in the tests.

Change-Id: I23640f466a4cf0ce45a0faa8df0246bfe8c404c3

subject: Expose volume host type and path independent of libvirt config

[{'created': '2018-01-02 18:14:52.000000000', 'message': "Expose volume host type and path independent of libvirt config

Currently the only driver-independent way to determine the type and path
of the host device used by a volume is to generate the full libvirt
config for the device. However, this requires both host and guest
context. For operations only interested in the host device, the guest
context is not required. This means that swap_volume is currently
required to fake the guest context.

This change exposes the host device information without having to
generate the full libvirt config. In doing so, we also simplify
libvirt config generation for drivers which don't customise anything
other than source type and path.

Change-Id: Ia6210a6cf6b005827ef8c2ad5243b997bbd89298
"}, {'created': '2018-01-04 15:46:25.000000000', 'message': 'Expose volume host type and path independent of libvirt config

Previously the only driver-independent way to determine the type and
path of the host device used by a volume wass to generate the full
libvirt config for the device. However, this requires both host and
guest context. For operations only interested in the host device, the
guest context is not required. Specifically this means that
swap_volume is required to fake the guest context in order to obtain
the host context, which is problematic.

This change exposes the host device information without having to
generate the full libvirt config. In doing so, we also simplify
libvirt config generation for drivers which don't customise anything
other than source type and path.

This has a couple of consequences. Firstly the is_block_dev parameter
to LibvirtBaseVolumeDriver becomes superfluous because this
information is available from get_host_type(). To avoid duplicating
this information we remove the parameter and use get_host_type()
instead. This highlighted a couple of instances of volume drivers
which were setting is_block_dev=False and source_type="block".
Specifically these were:

  LibvirtFibreChannelVolumeDriver
  LibvirtScaleIOVolumeDriver

The only impact of this would have been that the hypervisor driver for
the disk would be set incorrectly using either of these volume drivers
with libvirt/Xen, which is not a common configuration. It is fixed
with this patch.

Another consequence is that LibvirtVolumeDriver became a no-op class.
We remove it, and rebase all subclasses to LibvirtBaseVolumeDriver.

Change-Id: Ia6210a6cf6b005827ef8c2ad5243b997bbd89298

commit_message:
Expose volume host type and path independent of libvirt config

Previously the only driver-independent way to determine the type and
path of the host device used by a volume was to generate the full
libvirt config for the device. However, this requires both host and
guest context. For operations only interested in the host device, the
guest context is not required. Specifically this means that
swap_volume is required to fake the guest context in order to obtain
the host context, which is problematic.

This change exposes the host device information without having to
generate the full libvirt config. In doing so, we also simplify
libvirt config generation for drivers which don't customise anything
other than source type and path.

This has a couple of consequences. Firstly the is_block_dev parameter
to LibvirtBaseVolumeDriver becomes superfluous because this
information is available from get_host_type(). To avoid duplicating
this information we remove the parameter and use get_host_type()
instead. This highlighted a couple of instances of volume drivers
which were setting is_block_dev=False and source_type="block".
Specifically these were:

  LibvirtFibreChannelVolumeDriver
  LibvirtScaleIOVolumeDriver

The only impact of this would have been that the hypervisor driver for
the disk would be set incorrectly using either of these volume drivers
with libvirt/Xen, which is not a common configuration. It is fixed
with this patch.

Another consequence is that LibvirtVolumeDriver became a no-op class.
We remove it, and rebase all subclasses to LibvirtBaseVolumeDriver.

Change-Id: Ia6210a6cf6b005827ef8c2ad5243b997bbd89298

subject: Retire openstack-ansible unused roles

We'll want mnaser +1 as PTL before proceeding on this one"}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2019-04-18 13:41:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-18 19:16:41.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from retire-osa-unused-roles to project-update'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-18 19:16:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1 Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-04-18 23:04:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1 Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-04-19 15:06:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-04-23 10:14:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-23 10:28:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-25 20:26:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

JP: is there any reason why the governance related stuff has to be blocked by the code part?  This wasn't an issue with oslosphinx"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-26 07:46:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> JP: is there any reason why the governance related stuff has to be
 > blocked by the code part?  This wasn't an issue with oslosphinx

It was an issue with oslosphinx. We followed the procedure until the things where done, afaik. If the procedure is wrong, we need to change it. If the procedure is correct, we should follow it."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-04-28 21:56:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

> > JP: is there any reason why the governance related stuff has to
 > be
 > > blocked by the code part?  This wasn't an issue with oslosphinx
 > 
 > It was an issue with oslosphinx. We followed the procedure until
 > the things where done, afaik. If the procedure is wrong, we need to
 > change it. If the procedure is correct, we should follow it.

Steps 1-4 of that process need to be followed in order for technical reasons, but I don't think those steps are prerequisites for step 5 (removing a repo from governance). We should probably update the formatting the documentation to reflect that."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-05-06 17:42:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Isn't part of our job here to check that steps 1-4 are actually done? We very much don't want these repos to be left lying around in an apparently-usable state, so until the team responsible actually retires them then they remain the responsibility of that team from the TC's perspective.

If that's not what we're saying then I'd also be fine with Doug's suggestion to update the docs.

(Obviously I trust mnaser & team to get the right thing done regardless in this case, but it pays to set the right precedent.)"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-13 07:34:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Isn't part of our job here to check that steps 1-4 are actually
 > done? We very much don't want these repos to be left lying around
 > in an apparently-usable state, so until the team responsible
 > actually retires them then they remain the responsibility of that
 > team from the TC's perspective.
 > 
 > If that's not what we're saying then I'd also be fine with Doug's
 > suggestion to update the docs.
 > 
 > (Obviously I trust mnaser & team to get the right thing done
 > regardless in this case, but it pays to set the right precedent.)

[With TC hat] I agree with you.

[With member of community hat] There are people that stepped up and said they want to help on the ML. I don't see a compelling reason to remove the opportunity for those to step up in the OSA community.
If this is a direction the PTL wants to go (mnaser, it's your choice here :) ), then he should say so on the ML "we are not deprecating x because y and z", and not leave the options for people to step up. Then we can just follow the process.'}, {'account_id': 23327, 'date': '2019-05-13 10:04:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-05-13 12:26:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > Isn't part of our job here to check that steps 1-4 are actually
 > > done? We very much don't want these repos to be left lying around
 > > in an apparently-usable state, so until the team responsible
 > > actually retires them then they remain the responsibility of that
 > > team from the TC's perspective.
 > >
 > > If that's not what we're saying then I'd also be fine with Doug's
 > > suggestion to update the docs.
 > >
 > > (Obviously I trust mnaser & team to get the right thing done
 > > regardless in this case, but it pays to set the right precedent.)
 > 
 > [With TC hat] I agree with you.
 > 
 > [With member of community hat] There are people that stepped up and
 > said they want to help on the ML. I don't see a compelling reason
 > to remove the opportunity for those to step up in the OSA
 > community.
 > If this is a direction the PTL wants to go (mnaser, it's your
 > choice here :) ), then he should say so on the ML "we are not
 > deprecating x because y and z", and not leave the options for
 > people to step up. Then we can just follow the process.

I agree there should be further discussion on the ML. I can't find anything as of yet, but I'm still catching up.
If that's the case, could someone please add a link to the archive? I think I'm going blind.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-13 13:27:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > If this is a direction the PTL wants to go (mnaser, it's your

Before +1 to this release, could you provide why https://review.opendev.org/#/c/661738/ needed to be backported to stable/rocky? At least this kind of information would be helpful to understand the context (from the stable policy).'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2019-06-06 05:49:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

For the record ovsdbapp doens't assert the stable policy:

https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/src/branch/master/reference/projects.yaml#L1831-L1833"}, {'account_id': 8655, 'date': '2019-06-07 15:40:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Before +1 to this release, could you provide why https://review.opendev.org/#/c/661738/
 > needed to be backported to stable/rocky? I checked the change but
 > there is no information on the need of the backport and no bug is
 > associated. At least this kind of information would be helpful to
 > understand the context (from the stable policy).

Yes, we have this bugfix backported to networking-ovn: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662181/

but it requires that backport in ovsdbapp. The alternative is to copy the code to the ovn but I find it safer to backport into ovsdbapp and release because it has better test coverage.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-06-13 09:57:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Waiting for Akihiro's +1"}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-06-13 11:15:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Sorry for late.

> Yes, we have this bugfix backported to networking-ovn: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/662181/
> 
> but it requires that backport in ovsdbapp. The alternative is to copy the code to the ovn but I find it safer to backport into ovsdbapp and release because it has better test coverage.

Thanks for the information. This helps us understand the background and need of this change.
I checked the code you mentioned and it looks safe for backport. This looks good to me now.

I didn't know ovsdbapp does not follow the stable policy and it is a bit surprising to me.
(as I thought this is an essential part of OVS mechanism driver in neutron and networking-ovn)
It may be good to follow the stable policy in future."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-06-13 16:06:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Describe the business value of consistent RBAC

This has come up several times discussing community goals, but the
effort it going to require people to do the work. This commit attempts
to describe the benefit that a consistent RBAC implementation has for
the entire OpenStack platform and people who use it.

Change-Id: I3e5ef86df320f2fbe945926bff3cc8d76839d3fe

subject: Describe the business value of using unified limits
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 782, 'name': 'John Garbutt', 'email': 'john@johngarbutt.com', 'username': 'johngarbutt'}, {'_account_id': 1004, 'name': 'Mohammed Naser', 'email': 'mnaser@vexxhost.com', 'username': 'mnaser'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 5046, 'name': 'Lance Bragstad', 'email': 'lbragstad@redhat.com', 'username': 'ldbragst'}, {'_account_id': 5263, 'name': 'Jeremy Stanley', 'display_name': 'fungi', 'email': 'fungi@yuggoth.org', 'username': 'fungi', 'status': 'missing, presumed fed'}, {'_account_id': 10343, 'name': 'Jim Rollenhagen', 'email': 'jim@jimrollenhagen.com', 'username': 'jimrollenhagen'}, {'_account_id': 10607, 'name': 'Alexandra Settle', 'email': 'a.settle@outlook.com', 'username': 'asettle'}, {'_account_id': 11655, 'name': 'Julia Kreger', 'email': 'juliaashleykreger@gmail.com', 'username': 'jkreger', 'status': 'On the moon! With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-02-14 18:28:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-02-14 18:32:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-02-15 16:05:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Echoing Zane's excellent comment:

"I fear we may be leading ourselves off course by accident in using the term 'job description' here. The actual feedback from the board was not to put the list into the form of a job ad, but of a job *req*,
i.e. the business case a manager would make to their higher-ups to justify creating a position. The list of required skills for the candidate or whatever is irrelevant to that. Alan made very clear that it's coming up with a business justification that counts."'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-02-19 01:13:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

This is a great start. Some thoughts in-line.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-02-19 12:04:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

Modulo a variety of grammar issues and some additions that could go in (as others have noted) I think this is _great_.

This is what we were asked for. It is a description of a large need and the benefits that come from satisfying it, presented in a way that is comprehensible to people who think in terms of human resources.

It is something that can be given to platinum and gold members who are supposed to be on the hook to provide "FTE resources" with a "here's one way you could do that".

Thanks for getting this rolling Lance.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-02-19 19:21:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-02-19 19:33:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-02-19 19:54:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-02-20 13:34:57.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-02-28 14:43:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

(1 comment)

Acknowledging the earlier comments about the prior version being too "job description" I think this version goes too far the other way and while it outlines the business case for the work being _very well_ it leaves out the part that says "and we need some one or ones to do it, tyvm"

There's a business case, but it is more generic than a "business case a manager would make to their higher-ups to justify creating a position" because it leaves out "this is a position that needs to be filled" (I think...)

But overall it's great to see it laid out so clearly so gonna +1 anyway, and iteration is a thing.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-02-28 15:00:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-02-28 15:13:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

Revamping the "help most needed list" aside, I think this is a really well written case for why we would want more involvement in this effort and I think it would be a good thing to add.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-02-28 15:30:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> Revamping the "help most needed list" aside, I think this is a
 > really well written case for why we would want more involvement in
 > this effort and I think it would be a good thing to add.

Yeah - to further clarify. I added unified limits because it's a topic I'm very familiar with. If this sort of thing is useful to us or sponsors, I think we should consider revamping others on the list, ideally from the original authors.

It would be interesting to see if we could do this prior to the JLM in Denver, but I also understand this is a late start.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-02-28 15:44:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

Very good, nothing to say.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-03-04 20:28:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-03-04 21:50:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-03-04 21:50:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-03-04 21:57:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-04 22:17:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-03-04 22:45:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-03-05 09:40:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-05 12:32:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-03-06 01:15:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This is a superb write-up of the technical case for this work, excellent job Lance.

I would be interested in getting Alan's feedback on this, because my interpretation of what he meant by "business case" would include "who is going to give me [more] money with this that otherwise wouldn't" (or, equivalently, "how will this save me money"). So I don't know if we're all the way there yet but I'm fine with adding this to the list as is if we're keeping the list.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-03-06 15:19:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-07 13:10:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I love this format! It makes the rest of the entries look odd though, so I feel like this change should be part of a larger discussion on how to change/evolve how we designate and communicate priority areas of work. (together with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/633798/ and https://review.openstack.org/#/c/636956/)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-03-07 16:31:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I love this format! It makes the rest of the entries look odd
 > though, so I feel like this change should be part of a larger
 > discussion on how to change/evolve how we designate and communicate
 > priority areas of work. (together with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/633798/
 > and https://review.openstack.org/#/c/636956/)

Yeah - I think we'll need to retrofit the rest of the items in the list if we agree this is useful."}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-03-08 12:43:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

Just some notes but I can't imagine I'll be terribly popular by making you do another patch."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-03-08 14:18:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-03-08 14:18:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-03-08 14:26:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote+1 Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-03-11 12:42:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-03-11 14:08:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-14 14:55:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-03-26 09:49:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-28 13:36:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

How many folks do we have working on this right now, and how many would we like to have?

Agree this is a good goal, curious if it's to the point that it needs to be on this list."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-03-28 13:45:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> How many folks do we have working on this right now, and how many
 > would we like to have?
 > 

That's a good question. There have been a few folks that have come and gone, but in total, the number is in the single digits. In an ideal world, with the APIs we have across projects, I would expect at least two developers to feel comfortable tackling this work per project. But, I also understand that's probably not going to happen :)

 > Agree this is a good goal, curious if it's to the point that it
 > needs to be on this list.

FWIW - I mostly used this as an exercise for rewriting the list and finding ways to relay business value based on Alan's feedback last year. My thought process was to use $SOMETHING as an example for describing business value with the goal of building out a template that we could apply to the rest of the list. $SOMETHING just happen to be unified limits since I'm familiar with the topic and we get asked about it a bunch from operators. I contemplated abandoning the review after we hammered out a template and I started working through the other goals, but then it started getting +1s."}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-28 13:49:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Interesting, thanks Lance. commit_message:
Describe the business value of using unified limits

Recent threads on the openstack-discuss mailing list [0] suggest
revisting the idea of formatting the help-wanted list to represent job
requests that describe the value of an initiative to potential
sponsors. This was feedback the OpenStack Technical Committee received
from the Board of Directors during the Vancouver summit in 2018.

This is an attempt at doing that with an existing cross-project
initiative to consume unified limits.

[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-January/002252.html

Change-Id: I0cb4a0b1c0366afaa6d451d6c498d5b45b1fe242

commit_message:
Allow ability for non admin users to list all flavors.

Adds a new policy rule "os_compute_api:flavors:all" to control
whether a user can list or show all flavors including private
flavors.

Can be useful if you want to allow non-admins to view private
flavors, eg. help desk etc.

Closes-bug: #1796599

Change-Id: I715c3d0f3d7d754b4f4443ebfb9d3cda354bbbed

commit_message:
remove ec2 db functions

ec2 was deprecated in commit
f098398a836e3671c49bb884b4a1a1988053f4b2
back to mitaka release, this patch
starts to remove ec2 db related functions

Change-Id: Ife0ba655ef227543aa5e4957e39bc3c05a3c9dbf

(1 comment)

lgtm, just soft -1 for some improvements'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-26 15:55:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Long-term we're working toward modeling shared storage using resource provider aggregates in the placement service which would be managed externally to nova, i.e. some deployment tool that knows nodes A and B are in the same shared storage pool will create a resource provider that provides the DISK_GB resource inventory and has the MISC_SHARES_VIA_AGGREGATE trait, and then the providers for nodes A and B would be in an aggregate with the DISK_GB provider. That's how things would get modeled in placement. Shared storage providers aren't fully supported in nova yet, however, because there are various areas of the code that don't take them into account, like resource calculations during move operations (cold migrate for example). But once we have shared storage provider modeling supported in nova, I'd think that we can eventually just make hypervisor-stats use the placement API directly rather than deal with the legacy compute_nodes information in the database."}, {'account_id': 26286, 'date': '2018-07-27 09:01:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> Long-term we're working toward modeling shared storage using
 > resource provider aggregates in the placement service which would
 > be managed externally to nova, i.e. some deployment tool that knows
 > nodes A and B are in the same shared storage pool will create a
 > resource provider that provides the DISK_GB resource inventory and
 > has the MISC_SHARES_VIA_AGGREGATE trait, and then the providers for
 > nodes A and B would be in an aggregate with the DISK_GB provider.
 > That's how things would get modeled in placement. Shared storage
 > providers aren't fully supported in nova yet, however, because
 > there are various areas of the code that don't take them into
 > account, like resource calculations during move operations (cold
 > migrate for example). But once we have shared storage provider
 > modeling supported in nova, I'd think that we can eventually just
 > make hypervisor-stats use the placement API directly rather than
 > deal with the legacy compute_nodes information in the database.

@Matt Riedemann
Thank you for your advise. I think using placement API is the final solution. But it still need to deal with the legacy compute_nodes information in the database at present.  Especially for the Ocata, Pike and Queens branches who can only backport bug-fix patch."}, {'account_id': 26286, 'date': '2018-07-27 09:18:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 26286, 'date': '2018-07-27 09:20:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

[{'created': '2015-01-25 13:04:54.000000000', 'message': "hypervisor-stas show wrong disk usages with shared storage

While using shared storage like cph, each compute node reports its disk
usage with total backend pool disk usage, this makes sense to caculate
incoming resource request like booting a new instance or migrating instance
to this compute node. But while geting hypervisor-stats, we sum all the
compute nodes's disk usage, that doesn't make sense for ceph backend.
That will show that disk usage = {actual disk usage} * {number of
compuet node}

DocImpact: Add new config option shared_storage to indicate shared
storage for instances or not.

commit_message:
hypervisor-stats shows wrong disk usages with shared storage

While using shared storage like ceph, each compute node reports its disk
usage with total backend pool disk usage, this makes sense to calculate
incoming resource request like booting a new instance or migrating instance
to this compute node. But while getting hypervisor-stats, we sum all the
compute nodes's disk usage, that doesn't make sense for ceph backend.
That will show the {disk usage} = {actual disk usage} * {number of
compute node}

DocImpact: Add new config option shared_storage to indicate shared
storage for compute nodes or not.

Change-Id: I4525d8f508cb65b58c20b0ee72666bec8c65ef99
Closes-Bug: #1414432

'}, {'created': '2018-05-03 15:29:55.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Get inventories per vGPU type

Before passing multiple inventories per compute node to the Placement API,
we need an internal method for getting them.
Given the configuration, it will create an inventory for each supported vGPU
type so the next change will use those for updating the Placement API.

Change-Id: I910938f21f968410173ec68166e854261fe6d7b7

commit_message:
libvirt: Get inventories per vGPU type

Before passing multiple inventories per compute node to the Placement API,
we need an internal method for getting them.
Given the configuration, it will create an inventory for each supported vGPU
type so the next change will use those for updating the Placement API.

Change-Id: I910938f21f968410173ec68166e854261fe6d7b7
Partially-Implements: blueprint vgpu-rocky

commit_message:
libvirt: Configure multiple vGPU types

This patch adds new CONF options for libvirt to determine multiple
supported vGPU types.
Given only libvirt needs those options at the moment, that's why
those are in the libvirt module. In case more virt drivers will use
those, then moving the options would be needed.

For the moment, we don't use yet the new options, it will be done
in the next changes. Given that, I won't provide a reno file until
we directly support multiple types.

Partially-Implements: blueprint vgpu-rocky
Change-Id: I4681931a6fdd2bfc52b9d5729f84c3994f650fc9

commit_message:
Mask Passwords and allow Copy to Clipboard

This patch masks the IPMI password in the register nodes form
along with the Deployment Admin Password on a successful
deployment.

This also adds a 'Copy' button next to the Admin Password that
allows copying the password to the clipboard for future use.

Additionally, this patch allows the user to show/hide the Admin
Password.

I need some help on the following if anyone wants to jump in:
1. I don't know how to make use of the PasswordMask component
for just the input on the IPMI password field. Currently it's
being rendered using the Field component and accepting
HorizontalInput as it's component type which renders both label
and input. Any suggestions on a way to insert just PasswordMask
as the input component are welcome.

This patch adds two new dependencies:

* react-copy-to-clipboard [MIT] https://www.npmjs.com/package/react-copy-to-clipboard
* react-password-mask [MIT] https://github.com/zakangelle/react-password-mask

Change-Id: I1f04278ece8c4e3de8b09ef8eaa51c6ad4f9421f

[{'account_id': 11391, 'date': '2018-04-04 16:54:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10112, 'date': '2018-04-04 17:02:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Ideally for bug fixes, we have a release note. If you need help with that, please let me know.'}, {'account_id': 11391, 'date': '2018-04-04 17:29:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sure, np. Should I divide the commit into two and write a note to each one? Or is it ok to leave two fix bugs together in one patch?'}, {'account_id': 10112, 'date': '2018-04-04 19:06:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't think that's necessary :)  Thanks"}, {'account_id': 20970, 'date': '2018-04-04 19:16:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It's fine in one patch."}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-04-05 06:44:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

To switch to workflows, it will require to do changes in action creators rather than just changing that in constants which this patch does.

With this patch applied, GUI will try to still run actions with those new names which will fail.'}, {'account_id': 7509, 'date': '2018-04-05 06:45:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Also note that we're in process of transitioning to running workflows via startWorkflow action which makes running workflows more robust. So these changes should use the same"}, {'account_id': 11391, 'date': '2018-04-05 11:16:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-06-13 16:00:14.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

tripleo-ui has been retired, if this is still needed please target the appropriate branch'}]

commit_message:
Use workflows instead of actions

'tripleo.validations.list_validations' and 'tripleo.baremetal.validate_nodes'
actions are called directly as actions, but should instead be called via
workflows.

Change-Id: Idcf531c10980b78ad5fc23cf17a40ab4916198d7
Closes-bug: #1759417
Closes-bug: #1759415

subject: Remove the cap on the help needed list
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 5046, 'name': 'Lance Bragstad', 'email': 'lbragstad@redhat.com', 'username': 'ldbragst'}, {'_account_id': 8099, 'name': 'Graham Hayes', 'email': 'gr@ham.ie', 'username': 'graham'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 10343, 'name': 'Jim Rollenhagen', 'email': 'jim@jimrollenhagen.com', 'username': 'jimrollenhagen'}, {'_account_id': 10607, 'name': 'Alexandra Settle', 'email': 'a.settle@outlook.com', 'username': 'asettle'}, {'_account_id': 11655, 'name': 'Julia Kreger', 'email': 'juliaashleykreger@gmail.com', 'username': 'jkreger', 'status': 'On the moon! With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 12404, 'name': 'Rico Lin', 'email': 'ricolin@ricolky.com', 'username': 'rico.lin'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-03-14 15:15:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-03-19 19:54:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-03-19 23:56:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

I have serious concern that this could become a huge list instead of us choosing to change the community. That being said, with the number of projects, it makes sense to go ahead and have the space for greater than five items needed.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-03-20 19:20:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

make sense. We should be collecting the help items meeting criteria of whatever we will define next. Agree not to have number limit for that.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-03-21 10:35:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

I share Julia's concern. It's easy for us to add something to the list, and it's very difficult to remove anything. If we don't have a cap forcing us to make those prioritization calls and removing as much as we add, we will end up with a very long list with all projects (still) needing help... It won't be a list of where help is "most" needed, and it will be useless to our goal of channeling contributions to critical areas.

If 5 is too low to capture all priorities, maybe we should raise the cap ? Personally I think that above 8-10 items the list will no longer serve its purpose.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-03-21 13:35:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

Is it really the help *most* needed list if everything is on it? This sounds like a cop-out to avoid the TC having to make any decisions. When everything is the top priority that's the point where it tips from mostly useless to farce for me."}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-03-25 11:11:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1 Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-03-25 13:03:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Could we start ranking them if we let the list grow? I agree an unsorted, uncapped list will end up with too many items, and if everything is P0, nothing is.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-03-25 14:46:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Could we start ranking them if we let the list grow? I agree an
 > unsorted, uncapped list will end up with too many items, and if
 > everything is P0, nothing is.

I like this idea. I guess it depends on the direction we take with the business value of x.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-03-25 15:11:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-03-26 12:55:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Is it really the help *most* needed list if everything is on it?
 > This sounds like a cop-out to avoid the TC having to make any
 > decisions. When everything is the top priority that's the point
 > where it tips from mostly useless to farce for me.

If we take the decision to remove this idea of "help needed" but describe the business value of x, then it makes sense to remove the cap. I don't see how "help needed" ever had more impact, so I believe this is not how we should read this patch.

Should I refactor the commit message to express this?'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-03-26 20:01:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I share Julia's concern. It's easy for us to add something to the
 > list, and it's very difficult to remove anything. If we don't have
 > a cap forcing us to make those prioritization calls and removing as
 > much as we add, we will end up with a very long list with all
 > projects (still) needing help... It won't be a list of where help
 > is "most" needed, and it will be useless to our goal of channeling
 > contributions to critical areas.
 > 
 > If 5 is too low to capture all priorities, maybe we should raise
 > the cap ? Personally I think that above 8-10 items the list will no
 > longer serve its purpose.

I think 8 - 10 is fine, but ultimately I'd like to see the TC make a point to review this document on a regular cadence. We also don't need to make decisions about the contents of this list in a vacuum. We can have a forum session with operators, SIGs, and other stakeholders to help us set priority. Additionally, if we're going to be faced with pruning the list, we need criteria for items on the list so it's objective.

5 feels too low for the surface area of OpenStack. With the current state of the list, I don't think removing the wording here subjects us to copping out of the decision making process because we added two pretty major cross-project items. I might agree if the current help wanted list looked like the community goals etherpad [0].

[0] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/community-goals'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2019-03-26 20:02:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > I share Julia's concern. It's easy for us to add something to the
 > > list, and it's very difficult to remove anything. If we don't
 > have
 > > a cap forcing us to make those prioritization calls and removing
 > as
 > > much as we add, we will end up with a very long list with all
 > > projects (still) needing help... It won't be a list of where help
 > > is "most" needed, and it will be useless to our goal of
 > channeling
 > > contributions to critical areas.
 > >
 > > If 5 is too low to capture all priorities, maybe we should raise
 > > the cap ? Personally I think that above 8-10 items the list will
 > no
 > > longer serve its purpose.
 > 
 > I think 8 - 10 is fine, but ultimately I'd like to see the TC make
 > a point to review this document on a regular cadence. We also don't
 > need to make decisions about the contents of this list in a vacuum.
 > We can have a forum session with operators, SIGs, and other
 > stakeholders to help us set priority. Additionally, if we're going
 > to be faced with pruning the list, we need criteria for items on
 > the list so it's objective.
 > 
 > 5 feels too low for the surface area of OpenStack. With the current
 > state of the list, I don't think removing the wording here subjects
 > us to copping out of the decision making process because we added
 > two pretty major cross-project items. I might agree if the current
 > help wanted list looked like the community goals etherpad [0].

s/added/proposed/

 > 
 > [0] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/community-goals'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-03-27 12:28:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

I share the concerns about letting this list grow unbounded. It's not supposed to be "OpenStack's backlog".'}, {'account_id': 10343, 'date': '2019-03-28 13:32:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't think unbounded is necessarily bad, if we trust ourselves to not just add everything, and to be aggressive about removing things that have received the help they need. Do we?

If we do make a limit, what's stopping us from bumping it again in the future, with the same conversation?

Leaning +0 on this at the moment."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-04-04 12:24:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-05-04 15:32:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-06-13 15:33:59.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Remove the cap on the help needed list

If we add more projects in this list, it doesn't make sense to
keep a cap on the amount of "help needed list".

Change-Id: Ifc1462a7e9ff91196625042446de90362e3fcfe6

I'd like the unrelated fix to the unit test to be broken out of this patch, and there's one bit that could be respun without a regular expression. Overall I think this is pretty close to merging for os-vif. Decoupling the netdev requirement in os-vif makes this pretty much non-controversial. If you do a respin, feel free to take a look at some of the nits, but don't feel obligated.

Note, however, that the Nova side will still set the precedent that any future non-bifurcated solutions will have to have fixes applied in libvirt and the kernel. From my perspective, I'm fine with that (less code in Nova), but it's a good idea to check with the Nova cores and get buy-in."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-05-31 09:58:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

commit_message:
OVS DPDK port representors support

Adds support for OVS DPDK port representors[1], a direct
port on a netdev datapath is considered a DPDK representor port.

Using VIFHostDevice object with netdev in its profile means the port is
a DPDK representor port.

[1] http://docs.openvswitch.org/en/latest/topics/dpdk/phy/#representors

Closes-Bug: #1829734
Change-Id: I78e7dadfa44ac7e0ba6c9f31b3070011e783589f

commit_message:
Update json module to jsonutils

oslo project provide jsonutils, and magnum use it in many place[1],
this PS to update the remained json module to oslo jsonutils for
consistency.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/magnum/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=jsonutils&type=

Change-Id: I06910797c44c2b1bd2297d4398da9ab984a8f770

subject: Support multiple external networks in L3 agent
messages:
[{'account_id': 30484, 'date': '2019-06-13 15:15:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-06-13 15:15:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-06-13 15:18:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Empty commit, message copied from the neutron change.'}, {'account_id': 30484, 'date': '2019-06-13 15:19:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 30484, 'date': '2019-06-13 15:19:28.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-13 15:15:20.000000000', 'message': '
Support multiple external networks in L3 agent

Change [1] removed the deprecated option external_network_bridge. Per
commit message in change [2], "l3 agent can handle any networks by
setting the neutron parameter external_network_bridge and
gateway_external_network_id to empty". So the consequence of [1] was to
introduce a regression whereby multiple external networks are not
supported by the L3 agent anymore.

This change proposes a new simplified rule. If
gateway_external_network_id is defined, that is the network that the L3
agent will use. If not and multiple external networks exist, the L3
agent will handle any of them.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/567369/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/59359

Change-Id: Idd766bd069eda85ab6876a78b8b050ee5ab66cf6
Closes-Bug: #1824571
(cherry picked from commit 0b3f5f429d2e495eb78d78d46186092ac735e0d5)'}, {'created': '2019-06-13 15:19:08.000000000', 'message': 'Support multiple external networks in L3 agent

Change [1] removed the deprecated option external_network_bridge. Per
commit message in change [2], "l3 agent can handle any networks by
setting the neutron parameter external_network_bridge and
gateway_external_network_id to empty". So the consequence of [1] was to
introduce a regression whereby multiple external networks are not
supported by the L3 agent anymore.

This change proposes a new simplified rule. If
gateway_external_network_id is defined, that is the network that the L3
agent will use. If not and multiple external networks exist, the L3
agent will handle any of them.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/567369/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/59359

Change-Id: Idd766bd069eda85ab6876a78b8b050ee5ab66cf6
Closes-Bug: #1824571
(cherry picked from commit 0b3f5f429d2e495eb78d78d46186092ac735e0d5)

Revert "Pass network's dns_domain to dnsmasq conf"

The dns_domain attribute of a network is intended for use
by neutron when creating DNS records in an external DNS
system such as Designate.

By using the networks dns_domain, the configured search
path on booted instances mismatches with the generated
dns assignments for instance ports in the hosts file
for dnsmasq which creates a mismatched forward/reverse
lookup behaviour.

This reverts commit 7fdd6adc7acf99e74fbe1c12606f8c867ae134ae.
and commit 137a6d61053fb1cfb9a0a583b5a5c0f6253c75e6.

Closes-Bug: 1826419
Depends-On: I145144c042b100f7e12a02a8ac7e0fbbe41e984d
Change-Id: I5ff03b5ad8af432a9f7919ef953d7d8c434b93bd
'}]
commit_message:
Support multiple external networks in L3 agent

Change [1] removed the deprecated option external_network_bridge. Per
commit message in change [2], "l3 agent can handle any networks by
setting the neutron parameter external_network_bridge and
gateway_external_network_id to empty". So the consequence of [1] was to
introduce a regression whereby multiple external networks are not
supported by the L3 agent anymore.

This change proposes a new simplified rule. If
gateway_external_network_id is defined, that is the network that the L3
agent will use. If not and multiple external networks exist, the L3
agent will handle any of them.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/567369/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/59359

Change-Id: Idd766bd069eda85ab6876a78b8b050ee5ab66cf6
Closes-Bug: #1824571
(cherry picked from commit 0b3f5f429d2e495eb78d78d46186092ac735e0d5)

Revert "Pass network's dns_domain to dnsmasq conf"

The dns_domain attribute of a network is intended for use
by neutron when creating DNS records in an external DNS
system such as Designate.

By using the networks dns_domain, the configured search
path on booted instances mismatches with the generated
dns assignments for instance ports in the hosts file
for dnsmasq which creates a mismatched forward/reverse
lookup behaviour.

This reverts commit 7fdd6adc7acf99e74fbe1c12606f8c867ae134ae.
and commit 137a6d61053fb1cfb9a0a583b5a5c0f6253c75e6.

Closes-Bug: 1826419
Depends-On: I145144c042b100f7e12a02a8ac7e0fbbe41e984d
Change-Id: I5ff03b5ad8af432a9f7919ef953d7d8c434b93bd

commit_message:
Use auth_uri for Neutron API for Nova Placement

There is yet www_authenticate_uri for puppet-neutron in Queens.
This is a Queens only patch that fixes
https://review.opendev.org/663481 backport

Requires: https://review.opendev.org/664844

Change-Id: I9b4774209a7c982c58bb6e4ed681b468700e137b
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fixed the false InvalidConfigException for vfid=0

The InvalidConfigException is raised due to incorrect validation
of the parameters.

Change-Id: Icd1e55117caf65989cf91149d686080b0447d9bd
Closes-Bug: 1831853

commit_message:
Added new class neutron::server::placement

for neutron server.

commit_message:
Create Kuryr router for devstack deployment

For some gates (like OVN) there are problems using the router being
generated by default by devstack (router1.), such as FIPs not working.
This patch adds the possibility to generate an specific router for the
kuryr deployment, avoiding those problems.

Change-Id: I35f3be8fc16d71d0d2ac01c5451d398dd631f118

commit_message:
Parse the numa topology from the new flavor when resize instance

When resize the instance, the new flavor may includes new instance
topology request. Currently, the resize doesn't parse those from
the new flavor.

This patch adds the parsing of the numa topology request from the
instance image metadata and new flavor. Then update the new numa
topology request to the RequestSpec object.

Change-Id: I5e8b31c6079cd27f93c61ec5c5e79a6d23480a0b
Closes-bug: #1805767

[{'created': '2019-06-12 09:41:30.000000000', 'message': 'Skip test_check_doubled_words hacking check UT

The referenced bug has reared its ugly head in python 2.7.15 in (at
least) releaselevel='final', which is being used in the gate, as well as
3.6.7+. Disable the test entirely until we can fix or work around the
bug in the tokenizer.

The hacking check itself is still in place. This is just disabling the
unit test that tries to test the hacking check.

NOTE: Noticed that the hacking check is operating on physical_line,
which means it'll catch things like:

 "This is the the error"

but not:

 ("This is the "
  "the error")

...which is probably way more likely.

Change-Id: I8826c3fb89690805baae6b9b7b48985abb8d62d3
Related-Bug: #1804062
(cherry picked from commit 18ba6e6e6a7d1294bd1f1ece454f84eb65b219bb)
'}]
commit_message:
Skip test_check_doubled_words hacking check UT

The referenced bug has reared its ugly head in python 2.7.15 in (at
least) releaselevel='final', which is being used in the gate, as well as
3.6.7+. Disable the test entirely until we can fix or work around the
bug in the tokenizer.

The hacking check itself is still in place. This is just disabling the
unit test that tries to test the hacking check.

NOTE: Noticed that the hacking check is operating on physical_line,
which means it'll catch things like:

 "This is the the error"

but not:

 ("This is the "
  "the error")

...which is probably way more likely.

Change-Id: I8826c3fb89690805baae6b9b7b48985abb8d62d3
Related-Bug: #1804062
(cherry picked from commit 18ba6e6e6a7d1294bd1f1ece454f84eb65b219bb)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-12 14:34:28.000000000', 'message': 'Fix double word hacking test

At present, 'pycodestyle' feeds the following string into the 'tokenizer'
library:

    ["'This is the the best comment'"]

(note the added quotes because this isn't valid Python otherwise)

On previous versions of Python, this tokenizer would parse the string like so:

  (3, "'This is the the best comment'", (1, 0), (1, 30), "'This is the the best comment'")
  (0, '', (2, 0), (2, 0), '')

where (3 = 'STRING', 0 = 'ENDMARKER')

However, with the fix [1] backported to recent versions of Python, this now
resolves to:

  (3, "'This is the the best comment'", (1, 0), (1, 30), "'This is the the best comment'")
  (4, '', (1, 30), (1, 31), '')
  (0, '', (2, 0), (2, 0), '')

where (3 = 'STRING', 4 = 'NEWLINE', 0 = 'ENDMARKER')

Typically, 'pycodestyle' will run physical line checks on each line as it
parses the token:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2036

For the former case above, the line doesn't include a newline which
means we never parse a 'NEWLINE' token with a logical line (the fifth
element of the token tuple) corresponding to our full line. This means
triggers here but that wasn't an issue previously since there's a
fallthrough case that handled tokens remaining at the end of the parse:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2114-L2116

Unfortunately, because we now parse this separate 'NEWLINE' character, this
fallthrough case isn't activated, but neither is the physical line check
because the first token parsed still doesn't contain a new line character.
Instead we attempt to parse the "line" that the newline character is on and run
logical checks on the same:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2105-L2107

This is an issue since the logical check wipes stored tokens meaning
we've nothing to check when we get to the fallthrough case:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2012

This fixes changes things so that a newline is included (and also adds
quotes so it's valid Python, but that's mostly unrelated). This means we
end up with the following instead:

  ["'This is the the best comment'\n"]

On both Python without the bugfix and with it, this parses as:

  (3, "'This is the the best comment'", (1, 0), (1, 30), "'This is the the best comment'\n")
  (4, '\n', (1, 30), (1, 31), "'This is the the best comment'\n")
  (0, '', (2, 0), (2, 0), '')

where (3 = 'STRING', 4 = 'NEWLINE', 0 = 'ENDMARKER')

Which triggers things in 'pycodestyle' correctly.

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2044-L2046

This isn't _really_ a fix since there's clearly still a bug in either
'pycodestyle' or Python (I think the latter, since it's adding a newline
to a file that explicitly doesn't have one), but the chances of us
hitting this bug in practice are rather low - you'd need to make a
mistake on the very last line of a file without a newline at the end
which is something Vim, for example, won't even let you do without
setting special flags - and therefore it can be reasonably ignored.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1804062

Change-Id: Ia597594e0469c0e83d7ad22b0678390aaebaffe7
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1804062
'}, {'created': '2019-06-12 15:07:42.000000000', 'message': 'Fix double word hacking test

  (3, "'This is the the best comment'", (1, 0), (1, 30), "'This is the the best comment'")
  (0, '', (2, 0), (2, 0), '')

where (3 = 'STRING', 0 = 'ENDMARKER')

However, with the fix [1] backported to recent versions of Python, this now
resolves to:

  (3, "'This is the the best comment'", (1, 0), (1, 30), "'This is the the best comment'")

where (3 = 'STRING', 4 = 'NEWLINE', 0 = 'ENDMARKER')

Typically, 'pycodestyle' will run physical line checks on each line as it
parses the token:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2036

For the former case above, the line doesn't include a newline which
means we never parse a 'NEWLINE' token with a logical line (the fifth
element of the token tuple) corresponding to our full line. This means

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2114-L2116

Unfortunately, because we now have an additional newline character to

logical checks on it:

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2105-L2107

This is an issue since the logical check wipes stored tokens meaning

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2012

This fixes changes things so that a newline is included (and also adds

  (3, "'This is the the best comment'", (1, 0), (1, 30), "'This is the the best comment'\n")

where (3 = 'STRING', 4 = 'NEWLINE', 0 = 'ENDMARKER')

Which triggers things in 'pycodestyle' correctly.

  https://github.com/PyCQA/pycodestyle/blob/2.5.0/pycodestyle.py#L2044-L2046

This isn't _really_ a fix since there's clearly still a bug in either
'pycodestyle' or Python (I think the latter, since it's adding a newline
to a file that explicitly doesn't have one), but the chances of us
hitting this bug in practice are rather low - you'd need to make a
mistake on the very last line of a file without a newline at the end
which is something Vim, for example, won't even let you do without
setting special flags - and therefore it can be reasonably ignored.

[1] https://bugs.python.org/issue33899

Change-Id: Ia597594e0469c0e83d7ad22b0678390aaebaffe7
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1804062
